factoid: Weyrother was in full control of the proposed battle.
Weyrother was eager and brisk.
Kutúzov was dissatisfied and drowsy.
Kutúzov reluctantly played the part of chairman and president of the council of war.
Weyrother felt himself to be at the head of a movement that had already become unrestrainable.
Weyrother was like a horse running downhill harnessed to a heavy cart.
Weyrother did not know whether he was pulling the cart or being pushed by it.
Weyrother rushed along at headlong speed with no time to consider what the movement might lead to.
Weyrother had reconnoitered personally at the enemy’s picket line twice that evening.
Weyrother had reported and explained to the Russian and Austrian Emperors twice that evening.
Weyrother had dictated the dispositions in German at his headquarters twice that evening.
Weyrother was much exhausted when he arrived at Kutúzov’s castle.
Weyrother forgot to be polite to the commander in chief.
Weyrother interrupted the commander in chief.
Weyrother talked rapidly and indistinctly.
Weyrother did not look at the man he was addressing.
Weyrother did not reply to questions put to him.
Weyrother was bespattered with mud.
Weyrother had a pitiful, weary, and distracted appearance.
Weyrother was at the same time haughty and self‑confident.
Kutúzov was occupying a nobleman’s castle of modest dimensions near Ostralitz.
The large drawing room of the castle had become the commander in chief’s office.
Kutúzov, Weyrother, and members of the council of war were gathered in the large drawing room.
They were drinking tea while awaiting Prince Bagratión to begin the council.
Prince Bagratión’s orderly announced that Prince Bagratión could not attend.
Prince Andrew informed the commander in chief that Prince Bagratión could not attend.
Prince Andrew had permission previously given by Kutúzov to be present at the council.
Prince Andrew remained in the room after informing the commander in chief.
Weyrother said that since Prince Bagratión was not coming, they may begin.
Weyrother hurriedly rose from his seat.
Weyrother went up to the table on which an enormous map of the environs of Brünn was spread out.
Kutúzov had his uniform unbuttoned so that his fat neck bulged over his collar as if escaping.
Kutúzov was sitting almost asleep in a low chair.
Kutúzov had his podgy old hands resting symmetrically on the chair’s arms.
At the sound of Weyrother’s voice, Kutúzov opened one eye with an effort.
Kutúzov said, “Yes, yes, if you please! It is already late.”
Kutúzov nodded his head, let it droop, and again closed his eye.
The members of the council initially thought that Kutúzov was pretending to sleep.
The sounds his nose emitted during the reading proved that Kutúzov was absorbed in a far more serious matter than a desire to show contempt for the dispositions or anything else.
Kutúzov was engaged in satisfying the irresistible human need for sleep.
Kutúzov really was asleep.
Weyrother glanced at Kutúzov and, convinced he was asleep, took up a paper.
Weyrother read aloud the dispositions for the impending battle.
The dispositions were titled “Dispositions for an attack on the enemy position behind Kobelnitz and Sokolnitz, November 30, 1805.”
The dispositions were very complicated and difficult.
The dispositions described that the enemy’s left wing rested on wooded hills.
The dispositions described that the enemy’s right wing extended along Kobelnitz and Sokolnitz behind the ponds.
The dispositions described that the enemy’s left wing rested on wooded hills and his right extended along Kobelnitz and Sokolnitz behind the ponds.
